column1: Sentence
Duane Edgar Graveline (MD, MPH) (born on March 2, 1931 in Newport, Vermont) is an American physician and was a NASA astronaut.
He was one of the six scientists selected in 1965, in NASA's fourth group of astronauts, for the Apollo program.
He was consultant to magician David Blaine for Blaine's week of water immersion in 2006, correctly predicting Blaine's profound weakness from deconditioning.
Graveline was born on March 2, 1931 in Newport, Vermont.
He retired from family practice after twenty-three years and is now a writer of medical and science fiction.

column2: His current hobbies include medical consulting in zero gravity deconditioning and galactic cosmic radiation and personal health maintenance.

column1: Graveline graduated from Newport High School in 1948.
Following his internship at Walter Reed, he specialized in Aerospace Medicine, receiving his Masters in Public Health degree from Johns Hopkins University in 1958.
Graveline entered the United States Air Force Medical Service after graduation from medical college.
Graveline was granted the aeronautical rating of flight surgeon in February 1957.
From September 1957 to June 1958, he attended Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, where he received his Master's degree in Public Health.

column2: At this time he was assigned to the Aerospace Medical Research Laboratory as research scientist with special interest in prolonged weightlessness deconditioning and countermeasures.

column1: Graveline is the author of ten professional publications and reports on biological deconditioning and weightlessness countermeasures.

column2: His research has involved bed rest and water immersion to study deconditioning.

column1: NASA's operational lower body negative pressure device has seen used in the Soviet MIR, as well as on the shuttle and station research.
In June 1965, Graveline was selected with NASA's first group of scientist astronauts and assigned to Williams Air Force Base for jet pilot training.
He resigned due to personal reasons prior to being assigned to a mission and returned to civilian life.
Following his experience with cholesterol drug side effects, Graveline has become a critic of the use of statins to treat high cholesterol levels.
While on Lipitor, Graveline developed transient global amnesia and could not recognize his family.
He slowly recovered after stopping this medication.
NASA physicians then prescribed half the dose, but the amnesia returned.
He has no associations with pharmaceutical companies, receives no grants or funding from them or other state bodies.

column2: The book states that widely varying levels of cholesterol are inversely correlated with deaths from heart disease.
Higher levels are also inversely correlated with cancer mortality.

column1: That is, within a reasonable range, higher total cholesterol is associated with lower cancer mortality.
Graveline was a contributor to the book NASA's Scientist-Astronauts by David Shayler and Colin Burgess.
This article incorporates text from http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/graveline-de.html, which is a webpage by NASA.
